ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I come away from the course with a heightened ability to find, engage with, and write about primary source resources, which  will benefit me greatly when I write my senior thesis. Further, I have gained a more nuanced understanding of 20th century US history and how the forces of communism and anticommunism shaped it.
Communism in the US over the course of the 20th century
I feel like I got a really strong overview of the topic and improved at writing and researching.
History of socialism/communism in the United States, and its intersection with social and political movements.
Debating intellectual communism over the course of a century.
I learned a lot about the development of socialism in the United States and its interaction with other political institutions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was an excellent course, through and through! The only improvement I can think of is mixing up the structure of the seminar  sometimes the "read the assigned texts before, and class-discuss said texts in texts" loop got a bit repetitive.

Strengths: lots of feedback on writing, content touches on a lot
Weaknesses: frankly cannot think of any
I really liked this course. I cant think of anything to change.

Strength: Amazing professor, insightful class discussion, well-organized syllabus with a clear theme every week. It was also fascinating to not just learn about communism in the US (which was a relatively small movement in itself) but also how it influenced and shaped American society in significant ways.
Weakness: I know this is how history department seminars are structured, but the length of each class period (almost 2 hours) made it a bit exhausting, especially towards the end of each class.
Discussions were too broad. Reading was fantastic.

Strengths: great readings; class discussion was very engaging; research projects helped me learn how to conduct primary source research
Weakness: almost none, except it was a lot of readings -- not necessarily a weakness

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! If you are interested in history, you should take this course just to learn from Professor Gage. But further, if you already have a background in American history and want to hone your knowledge about the 20th century, this course provides a nuanced, complex, and interesting lens through which to do so.
Yes to anyone whos interested in American politics/social movements.
Yes. The material is worth knowing.

Yes! If you're interested in the history of socialism in the 20th century US and are willing to invest a significant amount of time to do readings and archival research, then you'll get a lot out of this class!
